title.en: Biographiy of the prince of Wei
title.raw: 《魏公子列傳》 Biographiy of the prince of Wei

sentences.zh: 魏公子無忌者，魏昭王子少子而魏安釐王異母弟也。

translations.literal: Lord Xinling of Wei, Wuji, was a younger son of King Zhao of Wei and a half-brother of King Anli of Wei.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Xinling of Wei, whose courtesy name was Wuji, was the youngest son of King Zhao of Wei and the half-brother of King Anli of Wei.

sentences.zh: 昭王薨，安釐王即位，封公子為信陵君。

translations.literal: When King Zhao passed away, King Anli ascended the throne and enfeoffed the prince as Lord Xinling.
translations.idiomatic: When King Zhao died and King Anli ascended the throne, he enfeoffed the prince as Lord Xinling.

sentences.zh: 是時范睢亡魏相秦，以怨魏齊故，秦兵圍大梁，破魏華陽下軍，走芒卯。

translations.literal: At this time, Fan Sui had fled from Wei to become prime minister of Qin, and because of his resentment toward Wei Qi, Qin troops besieged Daliang, defeating Wei's army below Huayang and routing Mang Mao.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Fan Sui had fled Wei to serve as prime minister of Qin. Due to his resentment of Wei Qi, Qin troops besieged Daliang, defeated Wei's army south of Huayang, and put Mang Mao to flight.

sentences.zh: 魏王及公子患之。

translations.literal: The King of Wei and the prince were troubled by this.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Wei and the prince were greatly troubled by this.

translations.literal: Lord Xinling of Wei, Wuji, was a younger son of King Zhao of Wei and a half-brother of King Anli of Wei. When King Zhao passed away, King Anli ascended the throne and enfeoffed the prince as Lord Xinling. At this time, Fan Sui had fled from Wei to become prime minister of Qin, and because of his resentment toward Wei Qi, Qin troops besieged Daliang, defeating Wei's army below Huayang and routing Mang Mao. The King of Wei and the prince were troubled by this.

sentences.zh: 公子為人仁而下士，士無賢不肖皆謙而禮交之，不敢以其富貴驕士。

translations.literal: The prince was benevolent by nature and humble toward scholars. Whether worthy or unworthy, he treated all scholars with modesty and courtesy, never allowing his wealth and nobility to make him arrogant toward them.
translations.idiomatic: The prince was benevolent by nature and deferential to scholars. Regardless of whether they were worthy or unworthy, he treated all scholars with humility and courtesy, never allowing his wealth and nobility to make him arrogant toward them.

sentences.zh: 士以此方數千里爭往歸之，致食客三千人。

translations.literal: Because of this, scholars from territories several thousand li around competed to come and attach themselves to him, bringing his retainers to three thousand men.
translations.idiomatic: Because of this, scholars from regions several thousand li around vied with one another to come and serve him, swelling his retainers to three thousand men.

sentences.zh: 當是時，諸侯以公子賢，多客，不敢加兵謀魏十餘年。

translations.literal: At this time, the feudal lords considered the prince worthy and having many retainers, so they did not dare invade or plot against Wei for over ten years.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, the feudal lords considered the prince worthy and well-attended by retainers, so they did not dare attack or plot against Wei for more than ten years.

translations.literal: The prince was benevolent by nature and humble toward scholars. Whether worthy or unworthy, he treated all scholars with modesty and courtesy, never allowing his wealth and nobility to make him arrogant toward them. Because of this, scholars from territories several thousand li around competed to come and attach themselves to him, bringing his retainers to three thousand men. At this time, the feudal lords considered the prince worthy and having many retainers, so they did not dare invade or plot against Wei for over ten years.

sentences.zh: 公子與魏王博，而北境傳舉烽，言「趙寇至，且入界」。

translations.literal: The prince was playing a board game with the King of Wei when the northern border beacon was lit, reporting 'Zhao invaders approaching, about to enter our territory.'
translations.idiomatic: The prince was playing liubo with the King of Wei when a messenger from the northern border lit the beacon, reporting: 'Zhao invaders are approaching and about to enter our territory.'

sentences.zh: 魏王釋博，欲召大臣謀。

translations.literal: The King of Wei put down his game and wished to summon ministers.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Wei set down his game pieces and wished to summon his ministers for consultation.

sentences.zh: 公子止王曰：「趙王田獵耳，非為寇也。」

translations.literal: The prince stopped the king, saying: 'The King of Zhao is out hunting, not invading.'
translations.idiomatic: The prince stopped the king, saying: 'The King of Zhao is merely out hunting, not invading.'

sentences.zh: 復博如故。

translations.literal: They resumed their game as before.
translations.idiomatic: They resumed their game as before.

sentences.zh: 王恐，心不在博。

translations.literal: The king was anxious, his heart not on the game.
translations.idiomatic: The king was fearful, his mind not on the game.

sentences.zh: 居頃，復從北方來傳言曰：「趙王獵耳，非為寇也。」

translations.literal: After a while, another messenger came from the north saying: 'The King of Zhao is hunting, not invading.'
translations.idiomatic: After a short while, another messenger came from the north saying: 'The King of Zhao is only hunting, not invading.'

sentences.zh: 魏王大驚，曰：「公子何以知之？」

translations.literal: The King of Wei was greatly astonished and asked: 'How did you know this?'
translations.idiomatic: The King of Wei was greatly astonished and asked: 'How did you know this, prince?'

sentences.zh: 公子曰：「臣之客有能深得趙王陰事者，趙王所為，客輒以報臣，臣以此知之。」

translations.literal: The prince replied: 'I have retainers who can thoroughly penetrate the King of Zhao's secret affairs. Whatever the King of Zhao does, my retainers immediately report it to me. That's how I know.'
translations.idiomatic: The prince replied: 'I have retainers who can deeply penetrate the King of Zhao's secret affairs. Whatever the King of Zhao does, my retainers immediately report it to me. That's how I know.'

sentences.zh: 是後魏王畏公子之賢能，不敢任公子以國政。

translations.literal: After this, the King of Wei feared the prince's wisdom and abilities, and did not dare entrust him with state affairs.
translations.idiomatic: After this, the King of Wei feared the prince's worthiness and abilities, and did not dare entrust him with governance of the state.

translations.literal: The prince was playing a board game with the King of Wei when the northern border beacon was lit, reporting 'Zhao invaders approaching, about to enter our territory.' The King of Wei put down his game and wished to summon ministers. The prince stopped the king, saying: 'The King of Zhao is out hunting, not invading.' They resumed their game as before. The king was anxious, his heart not on the game. After a while, another messenger came from the north saying: 'The King of Zhao is hunting, not invading.' The King of Wei was greatly astonished and asked: 'How did you know this?' The prince replied: 'I have retainers who can thoroughly penetrate the King of Zhao's secret affairs. Whatever the King of Zhao does, my retainers immediately report it to me. That's how I know.' After this, the King of Wei feared the prince's wisdom and abilities, and did not dare entrust him with state affairs.

sentences.zh: 魏有隱士曰侯嬴，年七十，家貧，為大梁夷門監者。

translations.literal: Wei had a reclusive scholar named Hou Ying, aged seventy, who was poor and served as the gatekeeper of Daliang's eastern gate.
translations.idiomatic: Wei had a reclusive scholar named Hou Ying, aged seventy, who lived in poverty and served as gatekeeper of the Yi Gate in Daliang.

sentences.zh: 公子聞之，往請，欲厚遺之。

translations.literal: The prince heard of him and went to invite him, wishing to give him generous gifts.
translations.idiomatic: The prince heard of him and went to invite him, wishing to bestow generous gifts upon him.

sentences.zh: 不肯受，曰：「臣修身絜行數十年，終不以監門困故而受公子財。」

translations.literal: Hou Ying refused to accept, saying: 'I have cultivated myself and purified my conduct for decades. I will never accept the prince's wealth just because I am impoverished as a gatekeeper.'
translations.idiomatic: Hou Ying refused to accept, saying: 'I have cultivated my person and purified my conduct for several decades. I will never accept the prince's wealth merely because I am impoverished in my position as gatekeeper.'

sentences.zh: 公子於是乃置酒大會賓客。

translations.literal: The prince then prepared wine and held a great banquet for his guests.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon the prince prepared wine and held a great gathering of his retainers.

sentences.zh: 坐定，公子從車騎，虛左，自迎夷門侯生。

translations.literal: When all were seated, the prince took his chariot and retinue, leaving the left seat empty, and personally went to welcome Hou Sheng of the eastern gate.
translations.idiomatic: When all were seated, the prince took his chariot and retinue, leaving the honored left seat empty, and personally went to welcome Master Hou of the Yi Gate.

sentences.zh: 侯生攝敝衣冠，直上載公子上坐，不讓，欲以觀公子。

translations.literal: Hou Sheng adjusted his worn clothes and hat, went straight up and sat in the prince's upper seat without yielding, wishing to observe the prince.
translations.idiomatic: Master Hou adjusted his worn robes and hat, went straight up into the chariot and sat in the prince's honored seat without yielding, wishing to observe the prince's character.

sentences.zh: 公子執轡愈恭。

translations.literal: The prince held the reins with even greater respect.
translations.idiomatic: The prince held the reins with even greater deference.

sentences.zh: 侯生又謂公子曰：「臣有客在市屠中，願枉車騎過之。」

translations.literal: Hou Sheng then said to the prince: 'I have a friend in the market butcher shop. I wish to trouble your chariot and retinue to pass by there.'
translations.idiomatic: Master Hou then said to the prince: 'I have a friend among the butchers in the market. I would like to trouble your chariot and retinue to pass by there.'

sentences.zh: 公子引車入市，侯生下見其客朱亥，俾倪故久立，與其客語，微察公子。

translations.literal: The prince drove his chariot into the market. Hou Sheng got down to see his friend Zhu Hai, deliberately standing for a long time, talking with his friend while carefully observing the prince.
translations.idiomatic: The prince drove his chariot into the market. Master Hou got down to see his friend Zhu Hai, deliberately standing for a long time while talking with his friend, carefully observing the prince's demeanor.

sentences.zh: 公子顏色愈和。

translations.literal: The prince's expression grew even more gentle.
translations.idiomatic: The prince's countenance grew even more composed.

sentences.zh: 當是時，魏將相宗室賓客滿堂，待公子舉酒。

translations.literal: At this time, Wei's generals, ministers, royal clan, and guests filled the hall, waiting for the prince to raise his wine cup.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Wei's generals, ministers, royal clansmen, and guests filled the hall, waiting for the prince to raise his wine cup.

sentences.zh: 市人皆觀公子執轡。

translations.literal: The market people all watched the prince holding the reins.
translations.idiomatic: All the people in the market watched the prince holding the reins.

sentences.zh: 從騎皆竊罵侯生。

translations.literal: His retinue all secretly cursed Hou Sheng.
translations.idiomatic: His chariot attendants all secretly cursed Master Hou.

sentences.zh: 侯生視公子色終不變，乃謝客就車。

translations.literal: Hou Sheng saw that the prince's expression never changed, so he took leave of his friend and got into the chariot.
translations.idiomatic: Master Hou saw that the prince's expression never changed, so he took leave of his friend and mounted the chariot.

sentences.zh: 至家，公子引侯生坐上坐，遍贊賓客，賓客皆驚。

translations.literal: When they arrived home, the prince led Hou Sheng to the upper seat and introduced him to all the guests. The guests were all astonished.
translations.idiomatic: Upon arriving home, the prince led Master Hou to the seat of honor and introduced him to all the guests. The guests were all astonished.

sentences.zh: 酒酣，公子起，為壽侯生前。

translations.literal: When the wine flowed freely, the prince rose and toasted Hou Sheng in front.
translations.idiomatic: When the wine flowed freely, the prince rose and offered a toast to Master Hou before him.

sentences.zh: 侯生因謂公子曰：「今日嬴之為公子亦足矣。

translations.literal: Hou Sheng then said to the prince: 'Today Ying has done enough for the prince.
translations.idiomatic: Master Hou then said to the prince: 'Today Ying has done enough for the prince.

sentences.zh: 嬴乃夷門抱關者也，而公子親枉車騎，自迎嬴於眾人廣坐之中，不宜有所過，今公子故過之。

translations.literal: Ying is just a gatekeeper of the eastern gate, yet the prince personally bent his chariot and retinue to welcome Ying from among the crowd in the great hall. There should be no excess, yet today the prince deliberately went to excess.
translations.idiomatic: Ying is merely the gatekeeper of the Yi Gate, yet the prince personally troubled his chariot and retinue to welcome Ying from among the crowd in the great hall. There should be no excess, yet today the prince deliberately exceeded propriety.

sentences.zh: 然嬴欲就公子之名，故久立公子車騎市中，過客以觀公子，公子愈恭。

translations.literal: However, Ying wished to fulfill the prince's reputation, so I deliberately made the prince's chariot and retinue stand long in the market, passing by travelers to observe the prince. The prince grew even more respectful.
translations.idiomatic: However, Ying wished to enhance the prince's reputation, so I deliberately made the prince's chariot and retinue stand long in the market, letting passersby observe the prince. The prince grew even more deferential.

sentences.zh: 市人皆以嬴為小人，而以公子為長者能下士也。」

translations.literal: The market people all considered Ying a petty man, but considered the prince a nobleman able to humble himself before scholars.'
translations.idiomatic: The market people all considered Ying a petty man, but considered the prince a noble elder able to defer to scholars.'

sentences.zh: 於是罷酒，侯生遂為上客。

translations.literal: The banquet then ended, and Hou Sheng became a chief retainer.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon the banquet ended, and Master Hou became a chief retainer.

translations.literal: Wei had a reclusive scholar named Hou Ying, aged seventy, who was poor and served as the gatekeeper of Daliang's eastern gate. The prince heard of him and went to invite him, wishing to give him generous gifts. Hou Ying refused to accept, saying: 'I have cultivated myself and purified my conduct for decades. I will never accept the prince's wealth just because I am impoverished as a gatekeeper.' The prince then prepared wine and held a great banquet for his guests. When all were seated, the prince took his chariot and retinue, leaving the left seat empty, and personally went to welcome Hou Sheng of the eastern gate. Hou Sheng adjusted his worn clothes and hat, went straight up and sat in the prince's upper seat without yielding, wishing to observe the prince. The prince held the reins with even greater respect. Hou Sheng then said to the prince: 'I have a friend in the market butcher shop. I wish to trouble your chariot and retinue to pass by there.' The prince drove his chariot into the market. Hou Sheng got down to see his friend Zhu Hai, deliberately standing for a long time, talking with his friend while carefully observing the prince. The prince's expression grew even more gentle. At this time, Wei's generals, ministers, royal clan, and guests filled the hall, waiting for the prince to raise his wine cup. The market people all watched the prince holding the reins. His retinue all secretly cursed Hou Sheng. Hou Sheng saw that the prince's expression never changed, so he took leave of his friend and got into the chariot. When they arrived home, the prince led Hou Sheng to the upper seat and introduced him to all the guests. The guests were all astonished. When the wine flowed freely, the prince rose and toasted Hou Sheng in front. Hou Sheng then said to the prince: 'Today Ying has done enough for the prince. Ying is just a gatekeeper of the eastern gate, yet the prince personally bent his chariot and retinue to welcome Ying from among the crowd in the great hall. There should be no excess, yet today the prince deliberately went to excess. However, Ying wished to fulfill the prince's reputation, so I deliberately made the prince's chariot and retinue stand long in the market, passing by travelers to observe the prince. The prince grew even more respectful. The market people all considered Ying a petty man, but considered the prince a nobleman able to humble himself before scholars.' The banquet then ended, and Hou Sheng became a chief retainer.

sentences.zh: 侯生謂公子曰：「臣所過屠者朱亥，此子賢者，世莫能知，故隱屠閒耳。」

translations.literal: Hou Sheng told the prince: 'The butcher I passed by, Zhu Hai—this man is worthy. The world does not know him, so he hides among the butchers.'
translations.idiomatic: Master Hou told the prince: 'The butcher I passed by, Zhu Hai—this man is worthy. The world does not recognize him, so he hides among the butchers.'

sentences.zh: 公子往數請之，朱亥故不復謝，公子怪之。

translations.literal: The prince went several times to invite him. Zhu Hai deliberately did not respond with thanks. The prince was puzzled by this.
translations.idiomatic: The prince went several times to invite him. Zhu Hai deliberately refused to respond. The prince was puzzled by this.

translations.literal: Hou Sheng told the prince: 'The butcher I passed by, Zhu Hai—this man is worthy. The world does not know him, so he hides among the butchers.' The prince went several times to invite him. Zhu Hai deliberately did not respond with thanks. The prince was puzzled by this.

sentences.zh: 魏安釐王二十年，秦昭王已破趙長平軍，又進兵圍邯鄲。

translations.literal: In the twentieth year of King Anli of Wei, King Zhao of Qin had already broken Zhao's Changping army and advanced to besiege Handan.
translations.idiomatic: In the twentieth year of King Anli of Wei, King Zhao of Qin had already defeated Zhao's army at Changping and advanced to besiege Handan.

sentences.zh: 公子姊為趙惠文王弟平原君夫人，數遺魏王及公子書，請救於魏。

translations.literal: The prince's sister was married to Lord Pingyuan, younger brother of King Huiwen of Zhao. She repeatedly sent letters to the King of Wei and the prince, pleading for rescue from Wei.
translations.idiomatic: The prince's sister was married to Lord Pingyuan, younger brother of King Huiwen of Zhao. She repeatedly sent letters to the King of Wei and the prince, pleading for rescue from Wei.

sentences.zh: 魏王使將軍晉鄙將十萬眾救趙。

translations.literal: The King of Wei sent General Jin Bi with a force of 100,000 to rescue Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Wei sent General Jin Bi with 100,000 troops to rescue Zhao.

sentences.zh: 秦王使使者告魏王曰：「吾攻趙旦暮且下，而諸侯敢救者，已拔趙，必移兵先擊之。」

translations.literal: The King of Qin sent an envoy to tell the King of Wei: 'I attack Zhao and will take it in a matter of days. Any feudal lord who dares rescue them—I will first destroy Zhao, then shift my troops to attack them.'
translations.idiomatic: The King of Qin sent an envoy to tell the King of Wei: 'I am attacking Zhao and will take it in a matter of days. Any feudal lord who dares rescue them—I will first destroy Zhao, then shift my troops to attack them.'

sentences.zh: 魏王恐，使人止晉鄙，留軍壁鄴，名為救趙，實持兩端以觀望。

translations.literal: The King of Wei was afraid and sent someone to stop Jin Bi, keeping the army encamped at Ye, nominally rescuing Zhao but actually sitting on the fence to wait and see.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Wei was afraid and sent someone to halt Jin Bi, keeping the army encamped at Ye, nominally rescuing Zhao but actually hedging to wait and see.

sentences.zh: 平原君使者冠蓋相屬於魏，讓魏公子曰：「勝所以自附為婚姻者，以公子之高義，為能急人之困。

translations.literal: Lord Pingyuan's envoys came to Wei one after another with coronets and canopies, rebuking Lord Xinling of Wei: 'The reason Sheng attached herself as your relative was because of your noble righteousness, your ability to urgently aid those in distress.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan's envoys came to Wei one after another with full ceremonial regalia, rebuking Lord Xinling of Wei: 'The reason Sheng allied herself with you in marriage was because of your noble righteousness, your ability to urgently aid those in distress.

sentences.zh: 今邯鄲旦暮降秦而魏救不至，安在公子能急人之困也！

translations.literal: Now Handan will fall to Qin any day, yet Wei's rescue does not arrive. Where is your ability to urgently aid those in distress?
translations.idiomatic: Now Handan will fall to Qin any day, yet Wei's rescue does not arrive. Where is your ability to urgently aid those in distress?

sentences.zh: 且公子縱輕勝，棄之降秦，獨不憐公子姊邪？」

translations.literal: Even if you disregard Sheng and abandon her to surrender to Qin, do you not pity your own sister?'
translations.idiomatic: Even if you disregard Sheng and abandon her to surrender to Qin, do you not pity your own sister?'

sentences.zh: 公子患之，數請魏王，及賓客辯士說王萬端。

translations.literal: The prince was troubled by this and repeatedly petitioned the King of Wei, and his retainers and debaters persuaded the king in countless ways.
translations.idiomatic: The prince was troubled by this and repeatedly petitioned the King of Wei, while his retainers and debaters persuaded the king in countless ways.

sentences.zh: 魏王畏秦，終不聽公子。

translations.literal: The King of Wei feared Qin and ultimately would not listen to the prince.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Wei feared Qin and ultimately would not heed the prince.

sentences.zh: 公子自度終不能得之於王，計不獨生而令趙亡，乃請賓客，約車騎百餘乘，欲以客往赴秦軍，與趙俱死。

translations.literal: The prince considered that he could never obtain permission from the king. He decided not to survive alone while letting Zhao perish. So he gathered his retainers and prepared over a hundred chariots and cavalry, intending to lead his retainers to charge the Qin army and die together with Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: The prince realized he could never obtain the king's permission. He resolved not to survive alone while Zhao perished. So he gathered his retainers and prepared over a hundred chariots and cavalry, intending to lead his retainers to charge the Qin army and die together with Zhao.

The prince's sister was married to Lord Pingyuan, younger brother of King Huiwen of Zhao. She repeatedly sent letters to the King of Wei and the prince, pleading for rescue from Wei. The King of Wei sent General Jin Bi with a force of 100,000 to rescue Zhao. The King of Qin sent an envoy to tell the King of Wei: 'I attack Zhao and will take it in a matter of days. Now Handan will fall to Qin any day, yet Wei's rescue does not arrive. Where is your ability to urgently aid those in distress? Even if you disregard Sheng and abandon her to surrender to Qin, do you not pity your own sister?' The prince was troubled by this and repeatedly petitioned the King of Wei, and his retainers and debaters persuaded the king in countless ways. The King of Wei feared Qin and ultimately would not listen to the prince. The prince considered that he could never obtain permission from the king. He decided not to survive alone while letting Zhao perish. So he gathered his retainers and prepared over a hundred chariots and cavalry, intending to lead his retainers to charge the Qin army and die together with Zhao.

sentences.zh: 行過夷門，見侯生，具告所以欲死秦軍狀。

translations.literal: On the way he passed the eastern gate and saw Hou Sheng. He fully explained his plan to die charging the Qin army.
translations.idiomatic: On the way he passed the Yi Gate and saw Master Hou. He fully explained his plan to die charging the Qin army.

sentences.zh: 辭決而行，侯生曰：「公子勉之矣，老臣不能從。」

translations.literal: After bidding farewell, he set out. Hou Sheng said: 'My prince, do your best. This old minister cannot follow you.'
translations.idiomatic: After bidding farewell, he set out. Master Hou said: 'My prince, do your best. This old minister cannot follow you.'

sentences.zh: 公子行數里，心不快，曰：「吾所以待侯生者備矣，天下莫不聞，今吾且死而侯生曾無一言半辭送我，我豈有所失哉？」

translations.literal: The prince had traveled several li when his heart was uneasy. He said: 'I have treated Hou Sheng with complete courtesy. The world all knows it. Now I am about to die, yet Hou Sheng has not even given me a single word or half a phrase to send me off. Have I perhaps offended him?'
translations.idiomatic: The prince had traveled several li when his heart grew uneasy. He said: 'I have treated Master Hou with complete courtesy. The whole world knows it. Now I am about to die, yet Master Hou has not even given me a single word or half a phrase to send me off. Have I perhaps offended him?'

sentences.zh: 復引車還，問侯生。

translations.literal: He turned his chariot back and asked Hou Sheng.
translations.idiomatic: He turned his chariot back and asked Master Hou.

sentences.zh: 侯生笑曰：「臣固知公子之還也。」

translations.literal: Hou Sheng smiled and said: 'I knew the prince would return.'
translations.idiomatic: Master Hou smiled and said: 'I knew the prince would return.'

sentences.zh: 曰：「公子喜士，名聞天下。

translations.literal: 'The prince loves scholars. His reputation is known throughout the world.
translations.idiomatic: 'The prince loves scholars. His reputation is known throughout the world.

sentences.zh: 今有難，無他端而欲赴秦軍，譬若以肉投餒虎，何功之有哉？

translations.literal: Now there is difficulty, yet without any other plan you wish to charge the Qin army—like throwing meat to a hungry tiger, what merit could there be?
translations.idiomatic: Now there is difficulty, yet without any other plan you wish to charge the Qin army—like throwing meat to a hungry tiger, what merit could there be?

sentences.zh: 尚安事客？

translations.literal: Why still bother with retainers?
translations.idiomatic: Why still bother with retainers?

sentences.zh: 然公子遇臣厚，公子往而臣不送，以是知公子恨之復返也。」

translations.literal: However, the prince has treated me generously. If the prince went and I did not send you off, I knew the prince would resent it and return.'
translations.idiomatic: However, the prince has treated me generously. If the prince went and I did not send him off, I knew the prince would resent it and return.'

sentences.zh: 公子再拜，因問。

translations.literal: The prince bowed twice and asked for advice.
translations.idiomatic: The prince bowed twice and asked for advice.

sentences.zh: 侯生乃屏人閒語，曰：「嬴聞晉鄙之兵符常在王臥內，而如姬最幸，出入王臥內，力能竊之。

translations.literal: Hou Sheng then dismissed others and spoke privately: 'Ying has heard that Jin Bi's military tally is always kept in the king's sleeping quarters. Lady Ruji is most favored and enters and leaves the king's sleeping quarters—she has the strength to steal it.
translations.idiomatic: Master Hou then dismissed others and spoke privately: 'Ying has heard that Jin Bi's military tally is always kept in the king's sleeping quarters. Lady Ruji is most favored and enters and leaves the king's sleeping quarters—she has the ability to steal it.

sentences.zh: 嬴聞如姬父為人所殺，如姬資之三年，自王以下欲求報其父仇，莫能得。

translations.literal: Ying has heard that Lady Ruji's father was killed by someone. Lady Ruji has been seeking revenge for three years. From the king downward, all wished to avenge her father's death, but none could achieve it.
translations.idiomatic: Ying has heard that Lady Ruji's father was killed by someone. Lady Ruji has been seeking revenge for three years. From the king downward, all wished to avenge her father's death, but none could achieve it.

sentences.zh: 如姬為公子泣，公子使客斬其仇頭，敬進如姬。

translations.literal: Lady Ruji wept to the prince, and the prince sent retainers to behead her enemy and respectfully present it to Lady Ruji.
translations.idiomatic: Lady Ruji wept to the prince, and the prince sent retainers to behead her enemy and respectfully present it to Lady Ruji.

sentences.zh: 如姬之欲為公子死，無所辭，顧未有路耳。

translations.literal: Lady Ruji wishes to die for the prince without hesitation, but simply lacks the opportunity.
translations.idiomatic: Lady Ruji wishes to die for the prince without hesitation, but simply lacks the opportunity.

sentences.zh: 公子誠一開口請如姬，如姬必許諾，則得虎符奪晉鄙軍，北救趙而西卻秦，此五霸之伐也。」

translations.literal: If the prince truly opens his mouth and asks Lady Ruji, she will certainly agree, then obtain the tiger tally and seize Jin Bi's army, rescue Zhao to the north and repel Qin to the west—this would be the campaign of the Five Hegemons.'
translations.idiomatic: If the prince truly opens his mouth and asks Lady Ruji, she will certainly agree, then obtain the tiger tally and seize Jin Bi's army, rescue Zhao to the north and repel Qin to the west—this would be the campaign of the Five Hegemons.'

sentences.zh: 公子從其計，請如姬。

translations.literal: The prince followed his plan and asked Lady Ruji.
translations.idiomatic: The prince followed his plan and asked Lady Ruji.

sentences.zh: 如姬果盜晉鄙兵符與公子。

translations.literal: Lady Ruji indeed stole Jin Bi's military tally and gave it to the prince.
translations.idiomatic: Lady Ruji indeed stole Jin Bi's military tally and gave it to the prince.

translations.literal: On the way he passed the eastern gate and saw Hou Sheng. He fully explained his plan to die charging the Qin army. After bidding farewell, he set out. Hou Sheng said: 'My prince, do your best. This old minister cannot follow you.' The prince had traveled several li when his heart was uneasy. He said: 'I have treated Hou Sheng with complete courtesy. The world all knows it. Now I am about to die, yet Hou Sheng has not even given me a single word or half a phrase to send me off. Have I perhaps offended him?' He turned his chariot back and asked Hou Sheng. Hou Sheng smiled and said: 'I knew the prince would return.' 'The prince loves scholars. His reputation is known throughout the world. Now there is difficulty, yet without any other plan you wish to charge the Qin army—like throwing meat to a hungry tiger, what merit could there be? Why still bother with retainers? However, the prince has treated me generously. If the prince went and I did not send you off, I knew the prince would resent it and return.' The prince bowed twice and asked for advice. Hou Sheng then dismissed others and spoke privately: 'Ying has heard that Jin Bi's military tally is always kept in the king's sleeping quarters. Lady Ruji is most favored and enters and leaves the king's sleeping quarters—she has the strength to steal it. Ying has heard that Lady Ruji's father was killed by someone. Lady Ruji has been seeking revenge for three years. From the king downward, all wished to avenge her father's death, but none could achieve it. Lady Ruji wept to the prince, and the prince sent retainers to behead her enemy and respectfully present it to Lady Ruji. Lady Ruji wishes to die for the prince without hesitation, but simply lacks the opportunity. If the prince truly opens his mouth and asks Lady Ruji, she will certainly agree, then obtain the tiger tally and seize Jin Bi's army, rescue Zhao to the north and repel Qin to the west—this would be the campaign of the Five Hegemons.' The prince followed his plan and asked Lady Ruji. Lady Ruji indeed stole Jin Bi's military tally and gave it to the prince.

sentences.zh: 公子行，侯生曰：「將在外，主令有所不受，以便國家。

translations.literal: As the prince set out, Hou Sheng said: 'A general in the field does not necessarily obey the ruler's commands, for the benefit of the state.
translations.idiomatic: As the prince set out, Master Hou said: 'A general in the field does not necessarily obey the ruler's commands, for the benefit of the state.

sentences.zh: 公子即合符，而晉鄙不授公子兵而復請之，事必危矣。

translations.literal: If the prince matches the tally but Jin Bi does not hand over the army to the prince and instead asks the king, the matter will certainly be dangerous.
translations.idiomatic: If the prince matches the tally but Jin Bi does not hand over the army to the prince and instead consults the king, the matter will certainly be dangerous.

sentences.zh: 臣客屠者朱亥可與俱，此人力士。

translations.literal: My retainer the butcher Zhu Hai can go with you. This man is a strong warrior.
translations.idiomatic: My retainer the butcher Zhu Hai can go with you. This man is a warrior of great strength.

sentences.zh: 晉鄙聽，大善；

translations.literal: If Jin Bi listens, it will be very good.
translations.idiomatic: If Jin Bi listens, it will be very good.

sentences.zh: 不聽，可使擊之。」

translations.literal: If he does not listen, Zhu Hai can strike him down.'
translations.idiomatic: If he does not listen, Zhu Hai can strike him down.'

sentences.zh: 於是公子泣。

translations.literal: The prince wept at this.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon the prince wept.

sentences.zh: 侯生曰：「公子畏死邪？

translations.literal: Hou Sheng said: 'Does my prince fear death?
translations.idiomatic: Master Hou said: 'Does my prince fear death?

sentences.zh: 何泣也？」

translations.literal: Why do you weep?'
translations.idiomatic: Why do you weep?'

sentences.zh: 公子曰：「晉鄙嚄唶宿將，往恐不聽，必當殺之，是以泣耳，豈畏死哉？」

translations.literal: The prince said: 'Jin Bi is a fierce and seasoned general. If I go, he may not listen and I must certainly kill him. That is why I weep. How could I fear death?'
translations.idiomatic: The prince said: 'Jin Bi is a fierce and seasoned general. If I go, he may not listen and I must certainly kill him. That is why I weep. How could I fear death?'

sentences.zh: 於是公子請朱亥。

translations.literal: The prince then invited Zhu Hai.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon the prince invited Zhu Hai.

sentences.zh: 朱亥笑曰：「臣乃市井鼓刀屠者，而公子親數存之，所以不報謝者，以為小禮無所用。

translations.literal: Zhu Hai smiled and said: 'I am just a market butcher wielding my knife, yet the prince has personally visited me several times. The reason I did not respond with thanks was that I considered small courtesies unnecessary.
translations.idiomatic: Zhu Hai smiled and said: 'I am just a market butcher wielding my knife, yet the prince has personally visited me several times. The reason I did not respond with thanks was that I considered small courtesies unnecessary.

sentences.zh: 今公子有急，此乃臣效命之秋也。」

translations.literal: Now the prince has urgent need—this is the time for me to give my life.'
translations.idiomatic: Now the prince has urgent need—this is the time for me to give my life.'

sentences.zh: 遂與公子俱。

translations.literal: He went with the prince.
translations.idiomatic: He went with the prince.

sentences.zh: 公子過謝侯生。

translations.literal: The prince passed by to take leave of Hou Sheng.
translations.idiomatic: The prince passed by to take leave of Master Hou.

sentences.zh: 侯生曰：「臣宜從，老不能。

translations.literal: Hou Sheng said: 'I should follow you, but I am old and cannot.
translations.idiomatic: Master Hou said: 'I should follow you, but I am old and cannot.

sentences.zh: 請數公子行日，以至晉鄙軍之日，北鄉自剄，以送公子。」

translations.literal: Please count the prince's travel days. On the day you reach Jin Bi's army, I will face north and cut my own throat to send off the prince.'
translations.idiomatic: Please count the prince's travel days. On the day you reach Jin Bi's army, I will face north and cut my own throat to send off the prince.'

sentences.zh: 公子遂行。

translations.literal: The prince set out.
translations.idiomatic: The prince set out.

If the prince matches the tally but Jin Bi does not hand over the army to the prince and instead asks the king, the matter will certainly be dangerous. My retainer the butcher Zhu Hai can go with you. This man is a strong warrior. If Jin Bi listens, it will be very good. If he does not listen, Zhu Hai can strike him down.' The prince wept at this. The prince passed by to take leave of Hou Sheng. Hou Sheng said: 'I should follow you, but I am old and cannot. Please count the prince's travel days. On the day you reach Jin Bi's army, I will face north and cut my own throat to send off the prince.' The prince set out.

sentences.zh: 至鄴，矯魏王令代晉鄙。

translations.literal: He reached Ye and forged the King's order to replace Jin Bi.
translations.idiomatic: He reached Ye and forged the King's order to replace Jin Bi.

sentences.zh: 晉鄙合符，疑之，舉手視公子曰：「今吾擁十萬之眾，屯於境上，國之重任，今單車來代之，何如哉？」

translations.literal: Jin Bi matched the tally but doubted it. He raised his hand and looked at the prince: 'Now I command a force of 100,000 encamped at the border—a heavy responsibility for the state. Yet you come alone in a chariot to replace me. What should I make of this?'
translations.idiomatic: Jin Bi matched the tally but doubted it. He raised his hand and looked at the prince: 'Now I command a force of 100,000 encamped at the border—a heavy responsibility for the state. Yet you come alone in a chariot to replace me. What should I make of this?'

sentences.zh: 欲無聽。

translations.literal: He wished not to obey.
translations.idiomatic: He wished not to obey.

sentences.zh: 朱亥袖四十斤鐵椎，椎殺晉鄙，公子遂將晉鄙軍。

translations.literal: Zhu Hai hid a forty-jin iron hammer in his sleeve and hammered Jin Bi to death. The prince then commanded Jin Bi's army.
translations.idiomatic: Zhu Hai hid a forty-jin iron hammer in his sleeve and hammered Jin Bi to death. The prince then commanded Jin Bi's army.

sentences.zh: 勒兵下令軍中曰：「父子俱在軍中，父歸；

translations.literal: He rallied the troops and gave orders in the army: 'If father and son are both in the army, the father returns home.
translations.idiomatic: He rallied the troops and gave orders in the army: 'If father and son are both in the army, the father returns home.

sentences.zh: 兄弟俱在軍中，兄歸；

translations.literal: If brothers are both in the army, the elder brother returns home.
translations.idiomatic: If brothers are both in the army, the elder brother returns home.

sentences.zh: 獨子無兄弟，歸養。」

translations.literal: If there are only sons with no brothers, they return home to care for parents.'
translations.idiomatic: If there are only sons with no brothers, they return home to care for parents.'

sentences.zh: 得選兵八萬人，進兵擊秦軍。

translations.literal: He obtained 80,000 selected troops and advanced to attack the Qin army.
translations.idiomatic: He obtained 80,000 selected troops and advanced to attack the Qin army.

sentences.zh: 秦軍解去，遂救邯鄲，存趙。

translations.literal: The Qin army withdrew, and Handan was rescued, preserving Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin army withdrew, and Handan was rescued, preserving Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙王及平原君自迎公子於界，平原君負ゆ矢為公子先引。

translations.literal: The King of Zhao and Lord Pingyuan personally welcomed the prince at the border. Lord Pingyuan carried a crossbow and arrows, leading the way for the prince.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Zhao and Lord Pingyuan personally welcomed the prince at the border. Lord Pingyuan carried a crossbow and arrows, leading the way for the prince.

sentences.zh: 趙王再拜曰：「自古賢人未有及公子者也。」

translations.literal: The King of Zhao bowed twice and said: 'Since ancient times, no worthy man has matched the prince.'
translations.idiomatic: The King of Zhao bowed twice and said: 'Since ancient times, no worthy man has matched the prince.'

sentences.zh: 當此之時，平原君不敢自比於人。

translations.literal: At this time, Lord Pingyuan did not dare compare himself to others.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Lord Pingyuan did not dare compare himself to others.

sentences.zh: 公子與侯生決，至軍，侯生果北鄉自剄。

translations.literal: The prince took leave of Hou Sheng. When he reached the army, Hou Sheng indeed faced north and cut his own throat.
translations.idiomatic: The prince took leave of Master Hou. When he reached the army, Master Hou indeed faced north and cut his own throat.

sentences.zh: 魏王怒公子之盜其兵符，矯殺晉鄙，公子亦自知也。

translations.literal: The King of Wei was angry that the prince had stolen his military tally and forged the killing of Jin Bi. The prince also knew this himself.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Wei was angry that the prince had stolen his military tally and forged the killing of Jin Bi. The prince also knew this himself.

sentences.zh: 已卻秦存趙，使將將其軍歸魏，而公子獨與客留趙。

translations.literal: After repelling Qin and preserving Zhao, he had his generals lead the army back to Wei, while the prince alone stayed with his retainers in Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: After repelling Qin and preserving Zhao, he had his generals lead the army back to Wei, while the prince alone stayed with his retainers in Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙孝成王德公子之矯奪晉鄙兵而存趙，乃與平原君計，以五城封公子。

translations.literal: King Xiaocheng of Zhao appreciated the prince's forging and seizing of Jin Bi's army to preserve Zhao. He consulted with Lord Pingyuan and enfeoffed the prince with five cities.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiaocheng of Zhao appreciated the prince's forging and seizing of Jin Bi's army to preserve Zhao. He consulted with Lord Pingyuan and enfeoffed the prince with five cities.

sentences.zh: 公子聞之，意驕矜而有自功之色。

translations.literal: The prince heard this and his heart became proud, showing a self-satisfied expression of merit.
translations.idiomatic: The prince heard this and became proud in heart, showing a self-congratulatory expression of merit.

sentences.zh: 客有說公子曰：「物有不可忘，或有不可不忘。

translations.literal: A retainer advised the prince: 'There are things that cannot be forgotten, and things that must be forgotten.
translations.idiomatic: A retainer advised the prince: 'There are things one cannot forget, and things one must forget.

sentences.zh: 夫人有德於公子，公子不可忘也；

translations.literal: If someone has shown virtue to the prince, the prince cannot forget it.
translations.idiomatic: If someone has shown kindness to the prince, the prince cannot forget it.

sentences.zh: 公子有德於人，願公子忘之也。

translations.literal: If the prince has shown virtue to others, I hope the prince will forget it.
translations.idiomatic: If the prince has shown kindness to others, I hope the prince will forget it.

sentences.zh: 且矯魏王令，奪晉鄙兵以救趙，於趙則有功矣，於魏則未為忠臣也。

translations.literal: Moreover, forging the King's command and seizing Jin Bi's army to rescue Zhao—toward Zhao this has merit, but toward Wei it is not the conduct of a loyal minister.'
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, forging the King's command and seizing Jin Bi's army to rescue Zhao—toward Zhao this has merit, but toward Wei it is not the conduct of a loyal minister.'

sentences.zh: 公子乃自驕而功之，竊為公子不取也。」

translations.literal: The prince then became proud and took credit for it—I secretly think this is not appropriate for the prince.'
translations.idiomatic: The prince then became proud and took credit for it—I secretly think this is not appropriate for the prince.'

sentences.zh: 於是公子立自責，似若無所容者。

translations.literal: Thereupon the prince stood and reproached himself, as if he had no place to hide.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon the prince stood and reproached himself, as if he had no place to hide.

sentences.zh: 趙王埽除自迎，執主人之禮，引公子就西階。

translations.literal: The King of Zhao swept and cleaned to welcome him personally, performing the rites of a host, leading the prince to the west stairs.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Zhao swept and cleaned to welcome him personally, performing the rites of a host, leading the prince to the west stairs.

sentences.zh: 公子側行辭讓，從東階上。

translations.literal: The prince walked sideways in refusal, ascending from the east stairs.
translations.idiomatic: The prince walked sideways in refusal, ascending from the east stairs.

sentences.zh: 自言罪過，以負於魏，無功於趙。

translations.literal: He spoke of his crimes, saying he wronged Wei with no merit to Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: He spoke of his crimes, saying he wronged Wei with no merit to Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙王侍酒至暮，口不忍獻五城，以公子退讓也。

translations.literal: The King of Zhao served wine until evening, his mouth unable to offer the five cities because the prince was so modest.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Zhao served wine until evening, his mouth unable to offer the five cities because the prince was so modest.

sentences.zh: 公子竟留趙。

translations.literal: The prince ultimately stayed in Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: The prince ultimately stayed in Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙王以鄗為公子湯沐邑，魏亦復以信陵奉公子。

translations.literal: The King of Zhao gave Xiang as the prince's bathing city. Wei also gave Xinling to support the prince.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Zhao gave Xiang as the prince's bathing city. Wei also gave Xinling to support the prince.

translations.literal: The prince heard that Zhao had reclusive scholars Mao Gong hiding among gamblers and Xue Gong hiding among wine sellers. The prince wished to see these two men, but both hid themselves and refused to see the prince.
translations.idiomatic: The prince heard that Zhao had reclusive scholars: Mao Gong hiding among gamblers and Xue Gong hiding among wine sellers. The prince wished to see these two men, but both hid themselves and refused to see the prince.

sentences.zh: 公子聞所在，乃閒步往從此兩人游，甚歡。

translations.literal: Lord Pingyuan heard of this and told his wife: 'At first I heard that your younger brother the prince was unmatched in the world. Now I hear that he casually travels with gamblers and ale sellers. The prince is indeed a frivolous man.'
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan heard of this and told his wife: 'At first I heard that your younger brother the prince was unmatched in the world. Now I hear that he casually travels with gamblers and ale sellers. The prince is indeed a frivolous man.'

sentences.zh: 平原君聞之，謂其夫人曰：「始吾聞夫人弟公子天下無雙，今吾聞之，乃妄從博徒賣漿者游，公子妄人耳。」

translations.literal: Lord Pingyuan heard this and told his wife: 'I once thought your brother the prince unmatched in the world, but now he frivolously befriends gamblers and ale sellers.'
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan heard this and told his wife: 'I once thought your brother the prince unmatched in the world, but now he frivolously befriends gamblers and ale sellers.'

sentences.zh: 夫人以告公子。

translations.literal: The wife told the prince.
translations.idiomatic: The wife told the prince.

sentences.zh: 公子乃謝夫人去，曰：「始吾聞平原君賢，故負魏王而救趙，以稱平原君。

translations.literal: The prince took leave of the wife and departed, saying: 'I once heard Lord Pingyuan was worthy, so I betrayed the King of Wei to rescue Zhao and match him.
translations.idiomatic: The prince took leave of the wife and departed, saying: 'I once heard Lord Pingyuan was worthy, so I betrayed the King of Wei to rescue Zhao and match him.

sentences.zh: 平原君之游，徒豪舉耳，不求士也。

translations.literal: Wuji, when I was in Daliang, often heard these two men were worthy. When I came to Zhao, I feared I would not meet them.
translations.idiomatic: Wuji, when I was in Daliang, often heard these two men were worthy. When I came to Zhao, I feared I would not meet them.

sentences.zh: 無忌自在大梁時，常聞此兩人賢，至趙，恐不得見。

translations.literal: That Wuji travels with them still fears they may not want me. Now Lord Pingyuan considers it shameful—it shows he is not worth traveling with.'
translations.idiomatic: That Wuji travels with them still fears they may not want me. Now Lord Pingyuan considers it shameful—it shows he is not worth traveling with.'

sentences.zh: 以無忌從之游，尚恐其不我欲也，今平原君乃以為羞，其不足從游。」

translations.literal: 'Now Lord Pingyuan considers it shameful—he is not worth traveling with.'
translations.idiomatic: 'Now Lord Pingyuan considers it shameful—he is not worth traveling with.'

sentences.zh: 乃裝為去。

translations.literal: The wife fully explained this to Lord Pingyuan.
translations.idiomatic: The wife fully explained this to Lord Pingyuan.

sentences.zh: 夫人具以語平原君。
